segments.text: Your customers aren't finding you the
way they used to. They're not just
typing into Google anymore. They're
pointing their phone at what they see.
They're asking chat bots what to buy.
They're comparing you against
competitors before you even know they
exist. And if you're still building
traditional funnels, landing pages,
email sequences, retargeting ads, you're
optimizing for a customer journey that
doesn't exist anymore. I'm Neil Patel. I
run one of the largest independent
marketing agencies in the world. and I'm
going to show you five trends that are
completely changing how people decide
what to buy online and what you need to
know about each one. Let's dive in.
Chapter one.
The way people search for products has
fundamentally changed and most brands
are still invisible in the moments that
matter the most. People just don't type
in black leather jacket anymore. They
just point their camera at what they
see. Google Lens now processes 20
billion visual searches a month with 4
billion related to Shopee. That's not
experimental. That's mainstream behavior
happening right now. And here's what's
actually happening. Someone sees a
product they like in a Tik Tok video or
Instagram or even real life. Instead of
trying to describe it with words, they
just open up their camera, point at it,
and Google Lens identifies it instantly,
complete with pricing, availability, and
where to buy. According to recent data,
only 10% of US adults use visual search
regularly right now, but 42% say they're
interested in trying it. And among Gen Z
and younger millennials, your future
customer base, 22% are already using it
to discover and buy products. Here's the
problem for brands. If your product
imagery isn't optimized for visual
search, if your metadata isn't accurate,
if you're not structured for image-based
discovery, you're invisible to these
shoppers. Amazon has seen a 70%
year-over-year increase in visual
searches. Google just introduced
shopping ads directly into Google Lens
results. This isn't coming, it's here.
If you sell physical products, you need
highquality images from multiple angles.
You need accurate product data that
visual AI can read. And you need to
understand that showing your product is
more powerful than describing it. A
study by MDG Advertising revealed that
67% of online shoppers believe that
highquality product images are more
important than product descriptions or
customer reviews. Chapter 2, trend two.
Live shopping compresses the decision
timeline. The gap between I'm interested
and I just bought it is collapsing and
is happening in real time. Live shopping
turns curiosity into instant action. In
2022, Facebook was a leading platform
for live commerce with 57.8% of global
internet users making purchases during
live shopping events. Instagram was
second at 45.8% followed by Tik Tok at
15.8%. Live streaming shopping market
was valued at 38.87
billion in 2022. By 2032, it's projected
to hit $256.56
billion. And here's why this matters.
Live shopping removes hesitation.
Instead of seeing a product, thinking
about it, researching it, and maybe
buying it later, people watch a live
demo, ask questions in real time, and
buy immediately. Traditional e-commerce
has friction. You see something, you
leave the platform, you research, you
compare, you get distracted, you abandon
cart. Live shopping eliminates all of
that. The product is demonstrated.
Social proof is visible in the comments.
Questions get answered instantly. And
the purchases happen without leaving the
stream. If you're not experimenting with
live shopping, whether on Tik Tok,
Instagram, or your own platform, you're
missing the shift from delayed purchase
to instant conversion. The brands
winning here aren't just selling
products. They're creating events.
They're building urgency. They're
converting browsers into buyers before
doubt has time to set in. Chapter 3.
Trend number three. AI is becoming the
first research destination. Your
customers aren't starting their product
research on a traditional Google search
result page anymore. They're asking AI,
whether it's through Google's AI mode or
Chad GBT or even AI overviews. And if
you're not visible there, you don't
exist. If AI doesn't know you exists,
your customers won't neither. Chad GBT
launched shopping research in November
2025. Within weeks, it became a go-to
tool for product discovery. The system
doesn't just answer questions. It
researches products across the web,
synthesizes reviews, compares specs, and
presents personalized buyers guide.
According to Yelp's 2025's AI shopper
behavior report, 66% of shoppers who
purchase more than once a week are using
AI assistants like Chat GBT to guide
their purchasing decisions, and 34% are
using it specifically for initial
product discovery. Amazon has Rufus.
Google is testing AI shopping features.
Perplexia offers shopping through its
pro tier. This isn't one platform. It's
the entire ecosystem shifting towards AI
mediated discovery. Here's what changes.
AI doesn't rank websites. It recommends
products. It pulls from reviews,
specifications, availability, and
pricing across the web. If your product
data isn't structured, if your reviews
aren't authentic, if your information is
incomplete, AI won't recommend you. Now,
what's really interesting about all of
this is that chat GBT shopping research
doesn't include Amazon. That's a massive
blind spot. But it also means smaller
brands have an opportunity to get
recommended without competing directly
against Amazon's catalog. This matters
because AI is becoming the new
distribution channel. And that means a
few things have to change. First, your
product information has to be easier for
AI to understand. Second, you need real
customer reviews that AI can actually
pull from. Third, your specs have to be
clear and accurate. And finally, your
pricing and availability needs to be
easy to find and upto-date because when
someone asks Chat GBT, "What's the best
project management tool for small
businesses?" Your brand either shows up
in that answer or it doesn't exist in
their consideration set. Now, if you
need help with all of this, you can
check out my ad agency, NP Digital,
where we help companies with setting up
their website and data so that way AI
can easily crawl and understand
everything and more importantly showcase
it to users who are potentially
interested in your product. Chapter
four, trend four, comparison shopping is
now the default. Brand loyalty isn't
dead, but it's conditional. And that
condition is simple. Are you better than
the alternative? People don't ask, "Is
this good?" They ask, "Is this better?"
According to SAP Demarcus, 60% of
consumers switch from a brand that they
were loyal to in 2025 because of cost.
But price isn't the only factor. 54% say
lower product quality weakens their
loyalty. 49% site price increases and
47% point to poor customer service.
Meanwhile, McKenzie found loyal
customers tend to buy more often and
show higher willingness to pay for
brands that deliver real value. Loyalty
still matters, but only when it's
earned. But here's what's different.
Comparison shopping used to require
effort. You had to open multiple tabs,
read different reviews, compare specs
manually. Now, a does it for you. Chai
GBT compares products side by side.
Visual search shows you alternatives
instantly. Social commerce lets you see
what everyone else is buying. This means
your product page can't just describe
your product anymore. It needs to answer
comparison questions before it's even
asked. Why are you better than the
alternative? What makes you worth the
price? What do your reviews say that
competitors don't? Because 73% of
consumers will adjust their spending to
maximize loyalty program benefits and
90% of loyalty program owners see
positive returns, averaging 4.8 times
their investment. But that only works if
your baseline product and experience are
competitive. Stop thinking about your
product in isolation. Start thinking
about it in context of every alternative
your customer is evaluating because
that's exactly how they're shopping.
Make comparison easy. Highlight
differentiators clearly. Use reviews
strategically and understand that
loyalty is now a value exchange, not a
given. Chapter five, trend number five.
Search happens everywhere, not just on
Google. The search bar evolved.
Discovery is happening across every
platform your customers use, and most
brands are only showing up on one.
According to our data, Instagram
processes 6.5 billion searches per
month. YouTube handles over 3 billion.
Tik Tok is becoming a new product search
engine for Gen Z. Chad GBT is emerging
as a trusted discovery tool. According
to Hostinger's 2025 social commerce
survey, 82% of consumers use social
media to discover and research products.
In the same study, YouTube leads product
research at 52% followed by Facebook at
45%, Instagram at 38% and Tik Tok at
34%. Hostinger's data also shows that
Tik Tok and Instagram dominate Jenz's
product discovery with 55% of Gen Z
favoring Tik Tok and Facebook remaining
the more popular with millennials rather
than Gen Z. Other 2025 Gen Z reports
back this up, finding that Tik Tok is a
top product discovery platform for Gen Z
at around 77% with Instagram close
behind at around 74% and YouTube used to
be roughly 41% for deeper product
research. These platforms are no longer
just discovery channels. They are
purchase destinations. Sprouto reports
that 39% of consumers make purchases on
Facebook, 36% on Tik Tok, and 29% on
Instagram when they are ready to buy.
This is what I call search everywhere
optimization. Your content needs to rank
not just on Google, but across every
discovery surface your customers
actually use. That means weaving
keywords naturally into video scripts,
captions, on-screen text, and
descriptions. Building topic clusters so
platforms map you as an authority,
optimizing for conversational search,
full questions, not just keywords.
Because platforms now read everything,
your audio, your captions, your
transcripts, your visual text. They're
matching all of it to user intent. If
you're only optimized for Google, you're
missing where your customers are
actually searching. You need to show up
on Instagram where they're browsing, on
YouTube where they're researching, on
Tik Tok where there's discovery, on Chat
GBT when they're comparing, and yes,
still on Google when they're verifying.
Because buying doesn't happen in funnels
anymore. It happens across ecosystems.
And the brands that win are the ones
showing up everywhere it matters.
Chapter six. Trend loyalty is real and
fleeting. There's a new type of customer
loyalty and it evaporates the second
something stops trending. Viral products
create instant loyalty. They also create
instant churn. According to SAP, 14% of
consumers are now classified as trend
loyal. They buy what's popular in the
moment. Driven by Tik Tok reviews, viral
drops social proof. But here's the
catch. 29% of consumers lose interest
the second a product stops trending. and
15% admit they buy products purely
because they're going viral, not because
they need them. This creates a paradox.
Social commerce drove $571 billion in
sales in 2023, projected to exceed 1
trillion by 2028. Millennials are
expected to account for 33% of social
commerce spending, Gen Z, accounts for
29%. But loyalty among these buyers
isn't deep. It's fast, emotional, and
tied to cultural moments. True loyalty,
the kind where customers stick with you
through algorithm changes and price
increases, has actually declined. In
2024, it dropped 5% and now it's at 29%
in 2025. Meanwhile, 53% of consumers are
silent loyalists. They buy consistently
but don't engage. And 48% exhibit
incentivized loyalty, meaning they're
only loyal because of discounts and
rewards. So, the question isn't how do
you get customers, it's how do we turn
fleeting attention into lasting
relationships? You can't ignore trends.
Viral moments drive discovery, but you
also can't build a business on hype
alone. The brands that win do both. They
ride the trend to get discovered. Then
they use personalized engagement,
loyalty programs, and genuine value to
convert trend-riven buyers into repeat
customers. Because 88% of customers who
trust a brand will return as repeat
buyers. And increasing retention by just
5% increases profits by 25% to 95%.
That's the real opportunity. Not just
chasing every trend, but turning trend
attention into trust. The truth is, the
way people discover, research, and buy
products has fundamentally changed.
Visual search, live shopping, AI
research comparison tools, and
fragmented platforms. These aren't
trends. They're the new normal. The
brands who win aren't just the ones with
best funnels. They're the ones who show
up everywhere their customers are
actually searching and turn attention
into loyalty. If you want to understand
